question.title: Environment Minister
question.notes: An inventor has built a gadget that makes planet friendly cars easier and cheaper to produce. Dave Gordon works for the big Flashpoint Motors factory in your area.

questions.text: Will the Minister meet with me to discuss the Government's plans for curbing global warming?
questions.feedback: The Minister wasn't able to meet with you and it wasn't the most important thing for your constituents either.

questions.text: What plans do the Government have to invest in companies that make environmentally friendly cars?
questions.feedback: Your constituent's discovery has helped you raise your media and party profile.

questions.text: Has the Minister ever considered colouring her hair?
questions.feedback: Be careful with silly questions. Your constituents read about them in the press.

questions.text: What is a carbon footprint?
questions.feedback: That question was related to the environment. It didn't ask about what the Government is doing though.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Business Minister
question.notes: An inventor has built a gadget that makes planet friendly cars easier and cheaper to produce. Dave Gordon works for the big Flashpoint Motors factory in your area.

questions.text: Will the Minister meet with me to discuss the Government's plans for helping small exporting companies benefit from world trade?
questions.feedback: The Minister wasn't able to meet with you. He told you to talk to Charlie Curtis over in Global Affairs.

questions.text: What plans do the Government have to invest in companies that make environmentally friendly cars?
questions.feedback: Your constituent's discovery has helped you raise your media and party profile.

questions.text: Has the Minister ever considered colouring his hair?
questions.feedback: Be careful with silly questions. Your constituents read about them in the press.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Global Affairs Minister
question.notes: A smuggler has sparked tensions between the US and Canada after being caught with a lorry load of stolen maple syrup on US soil. Canadian Government officials are seeking the man's release from a US jail with the help of the UK Ambassador.

questions.text: What steps are the Government taking to resolve the sticky situation between America and Canada?
questions.feedback: Good question on a hot media topic. The Minister gave an update on the latest negotiations.

questions.text: What do sheep count when they can't get to sleep?
questions.feedback: Serious questions only please!

questions.text: As the Minister knows a lot about global affairs, can he tell us what the difference is between a 'democracy' and an 'autocracy'?
questions.feedback: An autocracy is a country where a single ruler holds all the power to govern.

questions.text: Has the Minister estimated whether or not this crisis will affect the price of maple syrup in the UK?
questions.feedback: The Minister didn't think your question made much sense.

missed.feedback: Where were you? You missed questions about an international crisis.

question.title: Prime Minister
question.notes: MPs fill the House of Commons Chamber to be part of Prime Minister's Questions. This is when MPs have the chance to ask the PM about anything the Government is doing.

questions.text: Can the Prime Minister assure the students in my constituency, and those across the country, that the Government will guarantee a stable interest rate on student loans?
questions.feedback: A good question for your constituency.

questions.text: Our planet is suffering. Can the Prime Minister finally admit that the Government has dragged its feet on researching and developing new sources of energy?
questions.feedback: The Prime Minister thought your question was disloyal. You made the papers.

questions.text: What research is being done by the Government to find alternative sources of energy to fossil fuels?
questions.feedback: A good question for your party. The Prime Minister was able to talk about the Government's good work in this area.

questions.text: Does the Prime Minister know what the capital of Peru is?
questions.feedback: It's Jakarta - but why ask the PM that? Your questioning style was treated harshly by the papers: 'Clueless MP embarrasses party'.

questions.text: Online bullying is a disturbing new trend. What is the Government doing to combat this behaviour?
questions.feedback: The PM thanked you for your efforts on this issue in your constituency. He went on to explain the Government's recent work.

missed.feedback: PMQs is a great chance to check the work of the Government (and raise your profile).

question.title: Crime and Justice Minister
question.notes: UK: A Yob Nightmare, was the recent headline in the Daily Bumble. A few high profile incidents of youth crime have led to a crackdown on young people, on the streets and in the media.

questions.text: What steps have the Government taken to help police cope with the recent rise in crime?
questions.feedback: Your constituents and the press want to know too!

questions.text: How many violent crimes have been committed by young people in the past year?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer was far less than has been reported in the media.

questions.text: Does the Minister accept that the recent spate of crimes committed by young people is due to Government failure?
questions.feedback: Your question was slightly aggressive toward your own party and caught the attention of the media.

questions.text: What assessment has the Minister made of links between media reporting and fear of crime?
questions.feedback: Good question. Unfortunately the press didn't like it. And the Minister didn't have much of an answer prepared.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Prime Minister
question.notes: MPs fill the House of Commons Chamber to be part of Prime Minister's Questions. This is when MPs have the chance to ask the PM about anything the Government is doing.

questions.text: Can the Prime Minister assure the students in my constituency, and students across the country, that the Government will guarantee a stable interest rate on student loans?
questions.feedback: A good question for your constituency.

questions.text: Our planet is suffering. Can the Prime Minister finally admit that the Government has dragged its feet on researching and developing new sources of energy?
questions.feedback: A tough question. You strongly pointed out where you think the Government isn't pulling its weight.

questions.text: What research is being done by the Government to find alternative sources of energy to fossil fuels?
questions.feedback: You got some information, but your question also let the PM publicly talk about the Government's good work in this area. Remember, your party wants to win the next election.

questions.text: Does the Prime Minister know what the capital of Peru is?
questions.feedback: It's Jakarta - but why ask the PM that? Your questioning style was treated harshly by the papers: 'Clueless MP embarrasses party'.

questions.text: Online bullying is a disturbing new trend in my constituency. What is the Government doing to combat this behaviour across the UK?
questions.feedback: The Prime Minister thanked you for your efforts on this issue in your constituency. And he went on to explain the Government's recent work.

missed.feedback: PMQs is a great chance to check the work of the Government (and raise your profile).

question.title: Crime and Justice Minister
question.notes: UK: A Yob Nightmare, was the recent headline in the Daily Bumble. A few high profile incidents of youth crime have led to a crackdown on young people, on the streets and in the media.

questions.text: What steps have the Government taken to help police cope with the recent rise in crime?
questions.feedback: Your constituents and the press want to know too!

questions.text: How many violent crimes have been committed by young people in the past year?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer was far less than has been reported in the media.

questions.text: Does the Minister accept that the recent spate of crimes committed by young people is due to Government failure?
questions.feedback: Your question came across slightly aggressive toward the Government and caught the attention of the media.

questions.text: What assessment has the Minister made of links between media reporting and fear of crime?
questions.feedback: Good question. The Minister didn't have much of an answer prepared. The press didn't like it much though.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.
